item.title: Ethernet over Copper vs Bonded T1
item.description:
T1 lines have long been considered a reliable connection option for small to medium businesses, gaining traction as prices dropped in recent years. However, a new technology called Ethernet over Copper (EoC) offers even greater bandwidth at a lower cost and with simpler connectivity. EoC, like T1, uses existing twisted-pair telephone wiring commonly found in business locations. item.title: GigE and FastE Bandwidth Services
item.description:

Carrier Ethernet is becoming the preferred choice for medium to high bandwidth needs, replacing traditional DS3, T3, and SONET technologies. item.title: MegaPath Beefs Up Last Mile Access
item.description:
The main obstacle for companies aiming to boost their WAN (Wide Area Network) bandwidth is the “last mile” access problem. item.title: Fiber Is The New Wireline
item.description:
In the world of telecommunications, “wireline” traditionally refers to connections made through copper wires, while “wireless” implies no physical connections. However, “fiber optic” technology exists as a distinct category, utilizing physical cables but transmitting data through light rather than electricity.
